creditline: Gift of Ruth Lathrop Sikes in memory of her brother Bruce Sikes, 1967
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
text: The artificial Mount Tenpo_ is a famous scenic spot of Osaka. It was created by dredging the Aji River in 1831. Cherry trees and many restaurants covered Mount Tenpo_ and this scene is intended to be from an overlook of the Aji River. For entertainment, people go through two thick pillars with a hole, an auspicious tradition known from the Great Buddha Hall of the To_dai Temple in Nara, or from a scene in Jippensha Ikku's (1766-1831) "Strolling along the Tokaido (<I>To_kaido_chu_ hizakurige)," a comic novel about the misadventures of two travelers.
title: Osaka’s Aji River from the Rain Shelter on Mount Tenpō
